Stitch Steps: Begin with two rows of alternating running stitches.  Bring the needle to the front  of the fabric just outside first stitch in the shorter row.
Short Description: Alternating short and long running stitches that create a jagged or whimsical pattern.
Notes: Ideal for playful, random-effect fill stitches.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle 1st stitch short row and 1st stitch long row.
Tuck the needle under the 2nd stitch long row and 1st stitch short row
Tuck the needle under the 2nd stitch in the short row and 2nd stitch in the long row
Tuck the needle under the 3rd stitch in the long row and 2nd stitch in the short row
Tuck the needle under the 3rd stitch in the short row and the 3rd stitch in the long row
Continue with this pattern.
Begin with two rows of alternating running stitches.  Bring the needle to the front  of the fabric just outside first stitch in the longer row.
Tuck the needle under the first stitch in the longer row and the first stitch in the shorter row.
Tuck the needle under the "bridge" thread you just created between the rows and under the 2nd stitch in the longer row.
Tuck the needle under the "bridge" thread you just created between the rows and under the 2nd stitch in the shorter row.
Continue with this pattern.
Bring the needle to the front.
Short Description: A single straight stitch from point A to point B.
Notes: Used in groups for filling or accents.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back.
Bring the needle to the front in a corner of the stitch
Short Description: Radiating straight stitches from a center point, forming a starburst.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back in the center of the stitch and bring the needle to the front in an opposite corner of the stitch, pulling snuggly to form a hole/eyelet.
Continue making stitches from the center to the corners and side centers until all 8 stitches have been made.
Bring the needle to the front in a corner of the stitch
Short Description: Eyelet made with straight stitches forming a diamond shape.
Notes: Often used in drawn thread work.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back in the center of the stitch and bring the needle to the front in an opposite corner of the stitch, pulling snuggly to form a hole/eyelet.
Continue making stitches from the center to the sides of the diamond until the space is filled as desired.
Bring the needle to the front at the top left of the arrow.
Short Description: Three stitches forming a V or arrow shape.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back at the tip of the arrow and bring it to the front at the top right of the arrow.
Take the needle to the back at the tip of the arrow.
Make straight stitches scattered randomly to fill a space. Typically stitches are all different directions.
Short Description: Tiny, scattered straight stitches.

Stitch Steps: Make 2 straight stitches side by side.  Pairs are scattered randomly to fill a space.  Pairs are all different directions.
Straight stitch 3 or more stitches using the same holes to create a puffy full stitch.
Short Description: Overlapping short straight stitches creating an oval or petal shape.
Alternative Names: Seed Stitch (in some traditions), Seed Stitch (in some traditions)

Stitch Steps: Make at least 3 parallel stitches side by side.
Short Description: Grouped vertical straight stitches tied in the center.

Stitch Steps: Bring the thread to the front of the fabric behind the center of the parallel stitches, taking care not to catch the threads.  Tuck the needle under the stitches and out of the left side of the stitches.
Tuck the needle under all of the stitches from the right side to the left side.  Pull snuggly.
Tuck the needle under the stitches from the right side and to the back of the fabric under the knot.
Bring the thread to the front on one edge of the shape.  Make a straight stitch directly across the shape.
Short Description: Straight stitches radiating in a square or circle, layered tightly.
Notes: Used for textured fill or focal point.

Stitch Steps: Continue in this fashion so that each stitch crosses the previous stitches in the center of the shape unitl it is filled.  Stitches can be very close togther or leave a little space.
Decide how long the stitches will be.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric that distance from the start of the stitching line.
Short Description: Basic outline stitch with overlapping ends.

Stitch Steps: Go down at the beginning of the stitching line.
Come up a stitch length from the last stitch.
Go down at the end of the last stitch.  Repeat.
Complete the Back Stitch.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric next to the beginning of the first stitch.
Short Description: Thread woven through the base backstitch line.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under the first stitch, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or backstitch.
Continue to weave under each stitch, always going the OPPOSITE direction.
Complete the Back Stitch.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric next to the beginning of the first stitch.
Short Description: Backstitch wrapped with another thread.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under the first stitch, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or backstitch.
Continue to weave under each stitch always going the same direction.
The pekinese stitch is created on a base of backstitches. In this case we are working left to right.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric just above one of the back stitches.
Short Description: Backstitch with laced loops added.
Alternative Names: Chinese Stitch, Chinese Stitch, Looped Backstitch

Stitch Steps: Thread the needle under the backstitch 2 to the left, from the top down.
Thread the needle under the next backstitch to the right from the bottom up.
Repeat from step 2 until all backstitches have been woven.
Begin with two rows of alternating back stitches.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric just outside the first stitch in the longer row.
Short Description: Herringbone variation with step-like pattern.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under the first stitch in the longer row and the first stitch in the shorter row.
Tuck the needle under the "bridge" thread you just created between the rows and under the 2nd stitch in the longer row.
Tuck the needle under the "bridge" thread you just created between the rows and under the 2nd stitch in the shorter row.
Continue with this pattern.
Decide how long the stitches will be.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric that distance from the start of the stitching line.
Go down at the beginning of the stitching line.
Come up a stitch length from the last stitch.
Go down into the end of the at the last stitch slightly overlapping.  Repeat.
Optional:  Split back stitch around the shape to be filled.

If this stitch is being used for shading, divide the shape into as many pieces as you have colors.  The long/short stitches will overlap these section lines and determine the length of the long/short stitches.
Bring the needle to the front a "long" stitch length from the edge, inside of the shape.
Take the needle to the back just beyond the edge of the shape.
Next to the previous stitch, bring the needle to the front a "short" stitch length from the edge, inside of the shape.
Take the needle to the back just beyond the edge of the shape.
Alternate between short and long stitches until the desired space is filled with that color.
For the second color, create a new row of alternating long and short stitches, splitting the original stitches (slightly overlaping)
Continue until all colors have been used to fill the space.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: A slanted stitch good for curves and outlines.

Stitch Steps: Go down a stitch length away and come back up nearly back to the beginning of the stitching line.  Keeping the loose thread toward you pull the thread through.
Go down a stitch length away and come back up at the end of the previous stitch.
Keeping the loose thread toward you pull the thread through.  Repeat.
Complete the Stem Stitch.  Come up from the back of the fabric next to the beginning of the first stitch.
Short Description: Stem stitch wrapped with another thread.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under the first stitch, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or backstitch.
Continue to weave under each stitch always going the same direction.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Similar to stem stitch but thread passes underneath.

Stitch Steps: Go down a stitch length away and come back up nearly back to the beginning of the stitching line Keeping the loose thread away from you pull the thread through.
Go down a stitch length away and come back up at the end of the previous stitch, keeping the loose thread away from you pull the thread through.
Repeat.
This stitch alternates between the stem stitch and outline stitch.
Short Description: Twisting stitch used for lines or borders.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Go down a stitch length away and come back up nearly back to the beginning of the stitching line.  Keeping the loose thread toward you pull the thread through.
Go down a stitch length away and come back up at the end of the previous stitch.  Keeping the loose thread away from you pull the thread through.
Repeat from Step 3.
Begin with a series of parallel straight stitches as a foundation.  Bring the thread to the front just outside of the first foundation stitch.
Short Description: A short vertical anchor over a thread line.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle under the first foundation stitch from future foundation stitches back toward the beginning, keeping the thread above the stitch.
Take the needle under the second foundation stitch from future foundation stitches back toward the beginning, keeping the thread below the stitch.
Repeat for all foundation stitches, taking the needle to the back near the final foundation stitch.
For row 2, begin with keeping the thread below and alternate for each wrap.  For future rows, alternate below/above to be the opposite of the previous row.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Twisted knots along a base line.

Stitch Steps: Go down a stitch length away and come back up nearly back to the beginning of the stitching line.  Keeping the loose thread toward you pull the thread through.
Take the needle under the newly formed stitch from toward you to away from you.  This makes a loop around the stitch.
Make another loop around the stitch to the LEFT of the first loop.
Make the next stem stitch
Take the needle under the newly formed stitch & the first stitch from toward you to away from you.  This makes a loop around the stitch.
Make another loop around the stitch to the LEFT of the first loop.
Continue from step 5.
Bring the to be couched thread to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the stitching line.  Lay it in place for the first part of the line.
Short Description: Diagonal stitches forming a branching line.

Stitch Steps: The thorn stitch is a couching stitch where the couching lines are crosses with longer arms than legs.
At about a stitch length away from the end fo the stitching line, bring the 'Coucher' thread to the front of the fabric, just a bit to one side of the stitching line. (short leg)

Cross over the to be couched thread and take the needle to the back of the fabric on the other side of the to be couched thread both further along the line and further away from the to be Couched thread.  (long arm)
Bring the coucher thread to the front of the fabric on the same side, but back even with the first part of the stitch (short leg)

Cross over the to be couched thread and take the needle to the back of the fabric on the other side of the to be couched thread even with the far end of the last stitch and further away from the to be couched thread. (long arm)
Repeat for the length of the stitching line, securing the to be couched thread in place.
At the end of the stitching line, take the to be couched thread to the back of the fabric and secure.
Stitch long straight stitches to create a diamond grid to fill the space.
Short Description: Grid pattern of couched threads.

Stitch Steps: Stitch small straight stitches to tack down the grid at each crossing.
Note:  It is helpful to mark your fabric at least where the crossings should be so the lines will all be straight and even.
Stitch vertical parallel lines a stitch width apart to fill the space.
Short Description: Rows of horizontal stitches couched down.

Stitch Steps: Row 1: Bring the thread to the front of the fabric just to the left at the top of the first vertical line.
Tuck the needle underneath the next vertical line, piercing the fabric and leaving a small gap before and after the vertical line.
Skip a vertical line (thread goes on top) and repeat Step 3.
Repeat Steps 3 & 4 until the right end of the parallel lines.
Row 2:  Bring the thread to the front of the fabric just to the right of the first vertical line, below Row 1.
Skip a vertical line.  (Thread goes on top)
Tuck the needle underneath the next vertical line, piercing the fabric and leaving a small gap before and after the vertical line.
Repeat Steps 7 & 8 until the right end of the parallel lines.
Repeat Rows 1 & 2 until the bottom of the parallel lines.
Begin with a grid of long straight stitches, being sure that the horizontal rows are woven over and under the vertical rows.
Short Description: Colored threads couched to create plaid look.

Stitch Steps: Make 2 straight stitches to couch down the first two vertical stitches.
Skip 2 vertical stitches and couch down the next 2, repeating to the end of the vertical stitches
For the next row, couch down the first stitch with 2 stitches, then skip 2, then couch 2 so that the couching alternates with the first row.
Repeat from step 2 until all horizontal couching is completed.
Work horizonally in the same fashion so that alternating squares of the original grid are filled and "empty".
Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Linked looped stitches forming a chain.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric very near where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place the working thread behind the needle, then pull through.
Repeat.
Complete the Chain Stitch.  Come up from the back of the fabric next to the beginning of the first stitch.
Short Description: Chain stitch wrapped with another thread.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under both arms of the first stitch, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or backstitch.
Continue to weave under each stitch always going the same direction.

Complete the Chain Stitch.  Come up from the back of the fabric next to the beginning of the first stitch.  Whip the chain stitch. Come up from the back of the fabric next to the beginning of the first stitch again, opposite side.
Short Description: Chain stitch wrapped twice for extra texture.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under both arms of the first stitch IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION as the first series of whips, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or backstitch.
Continue to weave under each stitch always going the same direction.
Complete the Chain Stitch.  Come up from the back of the fabric next to the beginning of the first stitch.
Short Description: Only parts of the chain are wrapped.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under just one arm of the first stitch, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or backstitch.
Continue to weave under each stitch always going the same direction.
Complete the Chain Stitch.  Come up from the back of the fabric next to the beginning of the first stitch.
Short Description: Thread woven or laced through chain loops.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under both arms of the first stitch, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or backstitch.
Continue to weave under each stitch always going the OPPOSITE direction as the last stitch.
Complete the Chain Stitch.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric in the center of the second stitch.
Short Description: Backstitches placed over chain base.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric  in the center of the first stitch, bring the needle to the front of the fabric in the center of the 3rd stitch.
Repeat this backstitch down the center of the chain stitch.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Chain stitch with a twist for extra texture.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric to the left of where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place the working thread across the front of the needle and then behind the needle, then pull through.
Repeat.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Twist direction alternates with each stitch.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric to the left of where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place the working thread across the front of the needle and then behind the needle, then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric to the right of where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place the working thread across the front of the needle and then behind the needle, then pull through.
Repeat left then right until completion.
Short Description: Dual color chain formed in one pass.

Stitch Steps: Thread the needle with 2 threads.
Short Description: Overlapping loops in a slanted pattern.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric very near where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place ONE of the working threads behind the needle, then pull through, making sure to pull each thread snugly.  Only that color will show up.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric very near where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place THE OTHER working thread behind the needle, then pull through, making sure to pull each thread snugly.  Only that color will show up.
Repeat.  Try other patterns or more colors.
Begin by making a short straight stitch at the beginning of the stitch line.
Short Description: Stacked and raised chain stitches.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle to the front of the fabric a stitch length away, thread it through the short straight stitch and take the needle to the back of the fabric very near where it came out.  This forms the first chain.

Bring the needle to the front of the fabric a stitch length away, thread it through the short straight stitch and take the needle to the back of the fabric very near where it came out.  This forms the second chain.
Bring the needle to the front of the fabric a stitch length away, thread it under both sides of the first chain.
Continue making chains, always weaving under both sides of the chain 2 previous.
Begin with a foundation of short parallel straight stitches along the stitch line.
Short Description: Detached chain used for petals.
Alternative Names: Detached Chain Stitch, Detached Chain Stitch

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle to the front of the fabric next to the first foundation stitch.

Tuck the needle under the first foundation sittch (from future foundation stitches back towards the beginning) below where the thread is coming out. Keeping the thread away from you as you pull through.  This leaves a little "wrap" around the first foundation stitch.
Tuck the needle under the first foundation stitch in the opposite direction above the first wrap, do not pull through.
Take the working thread behind the needle going away from you, then pull the needle through.
Repeat for each foundation stitch.
Begin by making 1 chain on the stitching line.
Make one chain that leans to the left.
Make another chain in the first chain that leans to the right.
Skip a bit and repeat from step 1.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Daisy with extended anchor stitch.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric very near where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place the working thread behind the needle, then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric a distance from where it came out on the other side of the loop, tacking it in place.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Circular arrangement of chain stitches.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric very near where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place the working thread behind the needle, then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric very near where it came out, but on the other side of the loop, tacking it in place.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Closed loop chain with woven base.
Alternative Names: Twisted Chain Stitch, Twisted Chain Stitch

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric a stitch width to the right of where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Wrap the working thread across in front of the needle, then behind the needle, then pull through.
Tuck the needle under the thread very near where it first came out at the beginning of the stitch, taking care not to pull too tightly.
Repeat from Step 2.
This stitch is worked right to left.  Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the right end of the sitching line.
Short Description: Chain with extended feather-like ends.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric a stitch width to the left of where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Place the working thread behind the eye end of the needle, cross the needle in front and then behind the tip of the needle
Take the needle to the back of the fabric to tack the loop in place, coming out just to the right of the loop on the stitching line.
Repeat from step 2.

This variation uses long tailed chain stitches where the tails form a zigzag shape.  It is helpful to mark where the zig zag stitches will go.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric a stitch length beyond the tip of the end of the zigzags, in line with that last section.
Short Description: Overlapping looped chains for texture.

Stitch Steps: Make a detached chain stitch, but for the 'tacking' stitch, stitch the whole length of that zig, taking the thread to the back of the fabric at the end of the 'zig.'
Bring the needle to the front of the fabric a stech length beyond the tip of the next 'zig'.
Repeat from step 2 until all of the zig zags are full.
This stitch is worked right to left.  Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the right end of the sitching line.
Short Description: Looped stitches with tails, resembling wheat.

Stitch Steps: Holding the needle with your right hand alongside the stitch line, holding the working thread with your left hand pulling it down and to the left, wrap the needle going over top and down behind, again pulling it down and to the left.

Use your right fingertip to hold the wrap on the needle.  Take the needle to the back of the fabric a short distance from where it came out, and bring it back to the front of the fabric a stitch width away along the stitching line, DO NOT PULL THROUGH.
Place the working thread behind the needle, then pull through.
Repeat from step 2.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric to the left of the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Looped stitch forming a round berry.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle down on the stitching line a stitch length from the start of the stitching line and come up to the right of the stitching line matching the initial stitch.
Take the needle down on the stitching line at the same place as the last stitch, forming a V.   Come out a stitch length down the stitching line.
Weave the needle under both arms of the v and take it down near where it came out.
Repeat.
Create a small detached chain stitch
Short Description: Petal-shaped chain stitch.

Stitch Steps: Create a slight larger detached chain stitch around the first one.
Create a 3rd slightly larger detached chain stitch around the first 2.
Create a detached chain stitch.
Short Description: Triangular shape resembling a bullâ€™s head.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle to the front of the fabric to the left of the chain stitch.
Tuck the needle through the tacking stitch of the chain stitch
Take the needle to the back of the fabric to the right of the chain stitch.
Bring the needle to the front at the top left of the arrow. (horns)
Short Description: Split and angled chain variation.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back at the tip of the arrow and bring it to the front at the top right of the arrow.
Take the needle to the back at the tip of the arrow and bring it to the front a stitch length below.
Weave the needle under both arms of the v and take it down near where it came out.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Twisted looped stitch resembling a shell.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric a stitch width to the right of where it came out, and come up a stitch length away along the stitching line.
Wrap the working thread across in front of the needle, then behind the needle, then pull through.
Tuck the needle under the thread very near where it first came out at the beginning of the stitch, taking care not to pull too tightly.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the center base of the stitch and come up at the top of the stitch.
Place the working thread behind the needle, then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric to tack the loop in place.
Begin by making a small chain stitch along the main stitch line. Do not tack the loop down.
Short Description: Looped chain with a crest on top.

Stitch Steps: Take a small bite of fabric with the needle a stitch length away from the main stitch line, parallel to the stitch line, do not pull through.
Wrap the working thread around the needle, crossing in front and then around behind the needle and pull through.
Weave the needle under the 'bridge' created by the last step going toward future stitches.
Go down near the 'tacking' thread of the first chain, and take a bite to form the next chain.
Thread behind the needle and pull through.
Repeat from step 2.
This stitch is built on a framework of 3 parallel stitching lines.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric a stitch length in from beginning of the bottom stitch line.
Short Description: Knotted loops branching off a stem.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the beginning of the bottom stitch line, bringing it to the front two stitch lengths along the top stitch line.  Wrap the thread behind the needle and pull through.  This forms the first twisted chain stitch.

To form the second and future twisted chain stitches,take the needle to the back of the fabric between the legs of the previous twisted chain stitch on the center line.  Bring the needle to the front a stitch length away on either the top stitching line or the bottom stitching line (alternate).  Wrap the working thread behind the needle and pull through
Repeat Step 3
The sailor stitch is a combination of a chain stitch and a blanket stitch.  Begin by making a blanket stitch at the beginning of the stitch line.
Short Description: Twisted chain variation used in nautical embroidery.

Stitch Steps: Make a chain stitch along the stitching line.
Make a blanket stitch such that the stitch comes out inside of the previous chain.
Repeat from Step 2.
Begin by making a chain stitch on the stitch line.
Short Description: Curved chain for a wave-like motion.

Stitch Steps: Instead of tacking it down, make a second chain stitch just to the right of the first, but longer.
Instead of tacking it down, make a third chain stitch just to the right of the second, but longer.  This creates a chain triplet.
Make a chain stitch on the stitch line.
This time make the second and 3rd chains to the LEFT of the first.
Repeat from Step 1 alternating right and left with each chain triplet.
Use a bullion knot needle for best success, if not a millners needle.
Short Description: Thread twisted and stitched to form a small knot.
Notes: Great for flower centers and accents.

Stitch Steps: Come up where the knot should be, then sit the project down, this is a 2 handed stitch.
Left hand holds the working thread taught pulled toward you.  Right hand holds the needle perpendicular to and on top of the thread.
Wrap over & around once, twice, three times.
Take the needle back down very near where it came out, but do not pull through.
Pull on the working thread to snug the wraps around the needle and pull through.
Use a bullion knot needle for best success, if not a millners needle.
Short Description: Figure-eight knot more stable than French.

Stitch Steps: Come up where the knot should be, then sit the project down, this is a 2 handed stitch.
Left hand holds the working thread taught pulled toward you.  Right hand holds the needle parallel to the thread on the LEFT side of the thread. (arms crossed).
Tuck the tip of the needle under the thread, then twist it 90 degrees so it is perpendicular to the working thread and your hands are no longer crossed.
Take the working thread and wrap it over and around the tip of the needle.
Using your right fingertip to hold the wraps on the needle, take the needle to the back of the fabric, pulling on the working thread snugly as you pull the thread through.
Come up where the knot should be.
Short Description: Ornamental knot with a looped structure.

Stitch Steps: Holding the working thread near where it comes out of the fabric, twist the thread to form a small loop, with the working thread on the bottom of the loop.  Pull on the thread to adjust the size of the loop as desired.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric just inside the loop tacking it in place.
Pistil Stitch is a french knot or Colonial knot but instead of going down near where the thread came out, you go down a distance away.  The knot will end up on the far end.
Short Description: French knot with an extended tail.

Stitch Steps: Use a bullion knot needle for best success, if not a millners needle.
Come up where the knot should be, then sit the project down, this is a 2 handed stitch.
Left hand holds the working thread taught pulled toward you.  Right hand holds the needle perpendicular to and on top of the thread.
Wrap over & around once, twice, three times.
Take the needle back down where the knot should be, but do not pull through.
Pull on the working thread to snug the wraps around the needle, and BACK TOWARDS WHERE THE THREAD CAME OUT and pull through.
Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the stitch line.
Short Description: Twisted knot worked with a continuous thread.

Stitch Steps: At a stitch length away from the thread, take a small stitch/bite perpendicular to the stitch line and pull through.
Tuck the needle from the beginning of the stitch line under the newly made stitch.  Pull the needle through to make the first knot.
Repeat from step 2.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Line of twisted knots worked closely.

Stitch Steps: At a stitch length to the right of the thread, take a small stitch/bite perpendicular to the stitch line.  If you are stitching around an appliqued piece, catch both the background and the applique piece.  Do not pull through.
Wrap the working thread around the needle crossing in front first, then around behind, keeping it snug.
Pull the needle through.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the start of the sitching line.
Short Description: Coral knots combined with beads.

Stitch Steps: Thread a bead onto the needle, leaving the bead near the eye of the needle.

At a stitch length to the right of the thread, take a small stitch/bite perpendicular to the stitch line.  If you are stitching around an appliqued piece, catch both the background and the applique piece.  Do not pull through.
Wrap the working thread around the needle crossing in front first, then around behind, keeping it snug.
Pull the needle through.
Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the stitch line.
Short Description: Knot variation worked in a scroll pattern.

Stitch Steps: At a stitch length away from the thread, take a small stitch/bite perpendicular to the stitch line, DO NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread under the eye end of the needle and then under the tip end of the needle forming a circle.
Pull through gently so the circle closes around the working thread, but not too tight.
Repeat from step 2.
Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the top of the stitch location.
Short Description: Symmetrical knot with four points.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the bottom of the stitch location and pull through.
Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the right of the stitch location.

Lay the working thread down toward the left stitch location.  Tuck the needle under the first stitch, coming from above the thread.  Wrap the working thread behind the tip of the needle and pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the left of the stitch location and pull through.
The fly stitch forms a Y shape.
Short Description: V-shaped stitch used for borders or leaves.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the top left of the Y.
Take the needle down at the top right of the Y, coming out at the base of the V portion of the Y.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle down at the bottom of the Y.
Create the closed fly stitch line.
Short Description: Fly stitch with an added wrap.

Stitch Steps: Bring the thread to the front of the fabric next to the tail of the first fly stitch
Tuck the needle under the first tail, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or tail.
Continue to weave under each tail always going the same direction.
The closed fly stitch is a row of fly stitches stacked on top of one another.
Short Description: Fly stitch worked tightly closed.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the top left of the Y.
Take the needle down at the top right of the Y, coming out at the base of the V portion of the Y.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle down at the bottom of the Y.
Repeat.
The open fly stitch is a row of sly stitches side by side.
Short Description: Fly stitch worked loosely.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the top left of the Y.
Short Description: Fly stitch twisted before anchoring.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle down at the top right of the Y, coming out at the base of the V portion of the Y.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread over top of the needle, then behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle down at the bottom of the Y.
The feather stitch forms a series of Vs
Short Description: Open, branched stitch.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the top left of the V.
Take the needle down at the top right of the V, coming out at the base of the V.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.  The thread is now at the top of the next V.  Continue with Vs alternating left and right.
The feather stitch forms a series of Vs.  In this case, the outside of every other V forms parallel straight lines.
Short Description: Feather stitch with no space between arms.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the top of the left stitch line.
Take the needle to the back at the top of the right stitch line, coming out a stitch length along that same line.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.  The thread is now at the top of the next V.
Take the needle to the back just below the previous stitch on the left stitch line, coming out a stitch length along that same line.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.  The thread is now at the top of the next V.
Repeat from Step 3
The feather stitch forms a series of Vs.  In this case, the right side of each V forms a straight line.
Short Description: Feather stitch with only one arm.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the top of the right stitch line.
Take the needle down at the top of the left stitch line, coming back to the front a stitch length below on the right stitch line.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle down on the left stitch line even with where the thread came out, coming back to the front a stitch length below on the right stitch line.
Repeat from Step 4.
The feather stitch forms a series of Vs
Short Description: Two rows of feather stitches side by side.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the top left of the V.
Take the needle down at the top right of the V, coming out at the base of the V.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.  The thread is now at the top of the next V.  Continue with Vs alternating 2 to the left and then 2 to the right.

The feather stitch forms a series of Vs.  In this case there are 3 Vs on each side all starting at the same level.  Then alternating to the other side.  The stitch will be formed on a series of 7 parallel lines.
Short Description: Fine, delicate feather variant.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the top of the center stitch line.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the 3rd stitch line at the same level as where the thread came out,  wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the 2nd line at the same level as the previous stitch,  wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the 1st line at the same level as the previous stitch,  wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the 5th stitch line at the same level as where the thread came out,  wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the 6th line at the same level as the previous stitch,  wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the 7th line at the same level as the previous stitch,  wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.
Repeat from Step 3.
The feather stitch forms a series of Vs.  In this case, the outside of every other V forms parallel straight lines.  It is similar to the closed feather, but stretched out.
Short Description: Stitch arms are vertical.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the top of the left stitch line.
Take the needle to the back a stitch length down from the top of the right stitch line, coming out a stitch length along that same line.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.  The thread is now at the top of the next V.
Take the needle to the back a stitch length below the previous stitch on the left stitch line, coming out a stitch length along that same line.  Do NOT pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and then pull through.  The thread is now at the top of the next V.
Repeat from Step 3
The crossed feather stitch is made from two straight sided feather stitches.  Begin by making one row of straight sided feather stitch.
Short Description: Feather arms cross over.

Stitch Steps: Make a second straight sided feather stitch in the gaps between the first one.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the end of the stitching line.
At a stitch length to the right, take a bite of the fabric beginning below the stitching line and ending on the stitching line.
Wrap the working thread behind the tip of the needle, and pull through.
repeat
Create the blanket stitch line.
Short Description: Buttonhole stitch with whipping thread added.

Stitch Steps: Bring the thread to the front of the fabric next to the main line of the first blanket stitch
Tuck the needle under the first mainline stitch, taking care not to catch any threads on the fabric or stitch.
Continue to weave under each mainline stitch always going the same direction.
Two rows of buttonhole stitches "facing" one another.
Short Description: Two layers of buttonhole for depth.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the end of the stitching line.
Short Description: Buttonhole with tightly packed stitches.

Stitch Steps: At a half stitch length to the right, take a bite of the fabric beginning below the stitching line and ending on the stitching line a stitch length to the right.  (slanted blanket stitch)
At a stitch length to the right, take a bite of the fabric beginning below the stitching line and ending right next to the last blanket stitch.  (slanted opposite direction)
Take a bite of the fabric beginning at the same spot the last blanket stitch began, and ending on the stitching line a stitch legth to the right (slanted blanket stitch)
Repeat from Step 3.
A blanket stitch around a circle, with all stitches going through the center of the circle.
Short Description: Circular arrangement of buttonhole stitches.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the end of the stitching line.
At a stitch length to the right, take a bite of the fabric beginning in the center of the circle and ending at the edge of the circle.
Wrap the working thread behind the tip of the needle, and pull through.
repeat
Create a row of at least 5 bullion knot stitches such that the arms spread in the shape of a crown.
Short Description: Circular version of thorn stitch, dense in center.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the end of the stitching line.
Short Description: Two rows of buttonhole facing each other.

Stitch Steps: At a stitch length to the right, take a bite of the fabric beginning below the stitching line and ending on the stitching line.
Take the needle to the back a short distance along the stitching line, bringing the need to the front of the fabric slightly to the right of the base of the first blanket stitch.
Tuck the needle under the short tacking stitch (the one on the stitching line)
Repeat from step 2.
This stitch combines the blanket stitch and a feather stitch.  It is formed on 3 parallel lines.  Begin by bringing the needle to the front of the fabric at the top of the center stitch line.
Short Description: Alternating feathered edges using buttonhole motion.

Stitch Steps: Form a slanted blanket stitch the end of which is the right stitching line.

Take the needle to the back of the fabric just below where it came out on the center stitching line, brining it back to the front just below where it went down on the right stitching line.  DO NOT PULL THROUGH
Wrap the working thread behind the needle and pull through gently, guiding the thread towards the center stitch line.
Repeat from step 2, but on the left side.
Repeat alternating between left and right sides.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric at the end of the stitching line.
Short Description: Buttonhole variation with knots for texture.

Stitch Steps: Wrap the needle 3 times as if it were a french knot, then at a stitch length to the right, take a bite of the fabric beginning below the stitching line and ending on the stitching line.
Wrap the working thread behind the tip of the needle, and pull through.
repeat
Begin by making 1 row of blanket stitches across the space
Short Description: Blanket stitch variation creating honeycomb fill.

Stitch Steps: Slightly below the tips of Row 1 and halfway between the first two legs of Row 1, bring the thread to the front of the fabric.
Tuck the needle under the second leg of Row 1, then make a blanket stitch halfway between the 2nd and 3rd legs of Row 1.
Continue in this fashion to the right edge.
Continue making interlocking rows until the space is filled.
Backstitch around the shape to be filled, bringing the thread out on the left edge just below the top of the shape.
Short Description: Filling stitch using free-floating buttonholes.

Stitch Steps: Lay the working thread towards the right.
Weave the needle down under the first backstitch and over your working thread and pull through, but not tightly.
Repeat from step 2 until you are at the end of the first row.
Weave the needle over the right edge backstitch.
Now work the same stitches, but this time going to the left:  Lay the working rhead towards the left.
Weave the needle down between 2 stitches in the previous row and over your working thread and pull through, but not tightly.
Repeat from step 5 until you are at the end of the next row.
Repeat rows until the space is filled.
On the final row, go under the gaps in the previous row AND the backstitches along the bottom edge.

Backstitch around the shape to be filled, bringing the thread out on the right edge just below the top of the shape.  Take the thread to the back of the fabric on the left edge of the shape just below the top of the shape. This creates a "return".   Bring the thread to the front of the fabric very near where it went down.
Short Description: Detached buttonhole with a returning thread pass.

Stitch Steps: Lay the working thread towards the right.
Weave the needle down under the first backstitch and the "return" and over your working thread and pull through, but not tightly.
Repeat from step 2 until you are at the end of the first row.
Weave the needle under the straight stitch on the right edge of the first row.
Weave the needle under the straight stitch on the left edge of the first row creating the "return".
Repeat from step 2 until you have filled the shape.
On the final row, go under the gaps in the previous row AND the backstitches along the bottom edge.
Begin with a row of small straight stitches along the top edge of the shape.
Short Description: Looped filling stitch worked in rows.

Stitch Steps: Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the left edge of the shape, one stitch length down from the top.
Take the needle past the first straight stitch and weave under it going to the left.  Do not pull tightly, but just tight enough to make a gently loop.
Repeat to the end of the shape.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the right edge of the shape, bringing the needle back to the front a stitch length down from the last stitch.

Take the needle past the first loop (from the right0 and weave under the base of the loop where the threads cross, going to the right.  Do not pull tightly, but just tight enough to make a gently loop.
Repeat to the end of the shape.
Continue going left and right across the shape, weaving under the base of the loop each time.
If desired, the final row can be tacked down.
This stitch is worked on 2 parallel lines.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the bottom stitch line.
Short Description: Zigzag line made of slanted stitches meeting at a central spine.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back on the top stitch line 1 1/2 stitch widths from the end, coming back to the front 1/2 stitch width to the left.
Take the needle to the back a full stitch width to the right on the top stitch line, coming back to the front in the middle of the newly formed stitch.
Take the needle to the back on the bottom stitch line 1 1/2 stitch widths from the last stitch, coming back to the front 1/2 stitch width to the left.
Take the needle to the back a full stitch width to the right on the bottom stitch line, coming back to the front in the middle of the newly formed stitch.
Take the needle to the back on the top stitch line 1 1/2 stitch width from the last stitch, coming back to the front 1/2 stitch width to the left.
Repeat from Step 3
This stitch is worked on 2 parallel lines.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the bottom stitch line.
Short Description: Chevron elements spaced apart for decorative effect.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back on the top stitch line 1/2 stitch width from the end, coming back to the front 1/2 stitch width to the left (directly above where the thread came out initially)
Take the needle to the back a full stitch width to the right on the top stitch line, coming back to the front in the middle of the newly formed stitch.
Take the needle to the back on the bottom stitch line a full stitch width from the last stitch.
The double chevron stitch is made from two chevron stitches.  Begin by making one row of chevron stitches.
Short Description: Two rows of chevron layered for a bolder line.

Stitch Steps: Make a second chevron stitch in the gaps between the first one.
This stitch is worked on 2 parallel lines.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the bottom stitch line.
Short Description: Only one slanted half of the chevron shape is stitched.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric a stitch width along the bottom stitch line coming back to the front in the middle of the newly formed stitch.
Lay the working thread to the right and away from you at an angle.

Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the top stitch line even with the end of the first baseline stitch, coming back to the front just below where it came out.  Make sure the working thread is behind the needle and pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric 1/2 stitch to the right of the previous baseline stitch on the bottom stitch line, coming out right next to the first baseline stitch.
Repeat from step 2.

This stitch is a chevron stitch, but lacking the restriction of parallel stitch lines and standardized stitch lengths.  It is recommended that you mark the intended location of the random short stitch lines before you begin.
Short Description: Chevron rows offset for a woven appearance.

Stitch Steps: Stitch as you would a regular chevron stitch.
The herringbone stitch is worked on 2 parallel stitch lines.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the bottom stitch line.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric 2 stitch widths to the right on the top stitch line, bringing it back to the front 1 stitch width to the left along that top stitch line.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric 2 stitch widths to the right on the bottom stitch line, bringing it back to the front 1 stitch width to the left along that bottom stitch line.
Repeat from step 2.
Begin with a row of herringbone stitch.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric next to the beginning herringbone stitch.
Short Description: Basic herringbone stitch with an extra thread woven through.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under that first diagonal stitch, coming out to the left of the next cross.  As you pull it tighter, the thread will go over the cross.
Tuck the needle under the next diagonal stitch, coming out to the left of the next cross.
Repeat Step 3 to the end of the herringbone row.
This stitch adds a cross stitch on top of each cross in the herringbone stitch.  Begin with a row of herringbone stitch.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric just outside the first cross.
Short Description: Herringbone stitch secured with vertical tacking stitches.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the other side of the cross, bringing it back to the front just outside the next cross.
Repeat step 2 until all crosses have vertical stitches.
Bring the needle to the front of the fabric just to the left of the first cross.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric on the other side of the cross, bringing it back to the front just to the left of the next cross.
Repeat step 5 until all the crosses have horizontal stitches.

The tied herringbone stitch is a combination of herringone stitch and a coral knot stitch.  Begin with a row of herringbone stitch.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric next to the beginning herringbone stitch.
Short Description: Herringbone stitch with knots or ties across the arms.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under the first herringbone cross, do not pull through.
Wrap the working thread around the needle crossing in front first, then around behind, keeping it snug.
Pull the needle through.
Repeat for all crosses.

This is similar to the herringbone stitch, but the stitches are closer together, leaving no gaps between.  The herringbone stitch is worked on 2 parallel stitch lines.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the bottom stitch line.
Short Description: Stitches are closer together for a dense, filled look.
Notes: Effective as a border or filler.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric 2 stitch widths to the right on the top stitch line, bringing it back to the front 1 stitch width to the left along that top stitch line.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric 1 stitch widths to the right on the bottom stitch line, bringing it back to the front 1 stitch width to the left along that bottom stitch line.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric 1 stitch width to the right on the top stitch line, bringing it back to the front 1 stitch width to the left along that top stitch line.
Repeat from Step 3.
The double herringbone stitch is made from two herringbone stitches.  Begin by making one row of herringbone stitches.
Short Description: Two rows of herringbone, overlapping or mirrored.

Stitch Steps: Make a second herringbone stitch in the gaps between the first one.
Make a short straight stitch at the top & bottom of where the  circle or oval will be.   Optional:  add small straight stitches to the sides of where the circle/oval will be.

Bring the needle to the front of the fabric next to one of the tacking stitches.  Weave through each tacking stitch, taking care not to catch any threads until the circle or oval is filled as desired.

This stitch begins with an odd number of spokes -- all the same length radiating from a central point (forming a circle) typically 5 spokes, but sometimes 3 or 7.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric very near the center between any 2 spokes.
Short Description: Circular or oval shape filled with woven thread over spokes.
Notes: Used for flower centers or textured spots.

Stitch Steps: Going either clockwise or counterclockwise for the entire wheel, lay the thread lay on top of the next spoke, then tuck the needle under the following spoke and pull through.
Short Description: Circular stitch woven over spokes radiating from the center.

Stitch Steps: Repeat step 2 going round and round until the wheel is so full it hides the ends of each spoke.  Then take the needle to the back of the fabric near a spoke.

This stitch begins with an even or odd number of spokes -- all the same length radiating from a central point (forming a circle.) Bring the needle to the front of the fabric very near the center between any 2 spokes.
Going either clockwise or counterclockwise for the entire wheel, tuck the needle under the next two spokes and pull through.
Short Description: Circular stitch woven over spokes radiating from the center.

Stitch Steps: Back up one spoke and tuck the needle under the next 2 spokes and pull through.  As you circle around, be careful that the "wraps" lay neatly in a row.
Repeat step 3 until the circle is full.
This stitch begins with at least 2 parallel straight stitches, ideally about 1/8 to 1/4 inch apart.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric near the end of one of the straight stitches.
Tuck the needle under the straight stitch (if needed) so it is on the outside of the straight stitches.
Tuck the needle under the far straight stitch and pull gently.
Tuck the needle under the far (should be the other side) stitch and pull gently.
Repeat Step 4 keeping the tension even so that the original straight stitches aren't pulled together and all  'wraps' lay neatly side by side.

This stitch begins with a framework of an odd number of spokes.  These instructions are for 3 spokes, but 5, 7, or 9 would be fashioned similarly.  Only the baseline of this picot is attached to the fabric.  Place a long thin pin going down at the top of the picot and coming out at the center of the bottom edge of the picot.  Bring the needle to the front on the left end of the baseline.
Short Description: Raised bar made by weaving thread across parallel stitches.

Stitch Steps: Loop the thread behind the pin and go down at the right end of the baseline, coming out at the center of the baseline (right next to the pin)
Wrap the thread up the left side of the pin and around behind the pin.
Weave the needle under the outside thread, over the middle thread (in front of the pin) and under the other outside pin.  Pull very tight.
Weave the needle under the middle thread going back to the left.  Taking care not to pull too tightly or the picot will be very pointy.
Weave the needle under the outside thread, over the middle thread and under the other outside pin, taking care not to pull too tightly or the picot will be very pointy.
Repeat from Step 5 until the picot structure is full.  Take the needle to the back of the project and pull the pin.
This stitch is built on a foundation of short parallel straight stitches.  Bring the thread to the front of the fabric just below the center of stitch number 2.
Short Description: Detached loop formed over a pin and filled with woven thread.
Notes: Stands up from the fabric for texture.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle behind both stitch 1 and stitch 2 in that orderâ€¦twice, with the wraps falling to the outside of previous wraps.
Tuck the needle behind the next foundation stitch down.  Tuck the needle behind both of the previous 2 foundation stitches, twice, with the wraps falling to the outside of previous wraps.
Continue step 3 until all foundation stitches have been wrapped twice.
Take the thread to the front of the fabric just below the center of stitch number 2 again.
Repeat the same process, this time with the wraps falling to the other outside of previous wraps.
This stitch is worked from right to left.  Begin by bringing the needle to the front of the fabric at the right end of the stitching line.
Short Description: Knotted edging stitch forming a dense line.

Stitch Steps: At a stitch length to the right of the thread, take a small stitch/bite perpendicular to the stitch line.  If you are stitching around an appliqued piece, catch both the background and the applique pieceand  pull through.
Short Description: A knotted line stitch with a raised texture.
Notes: Often used for borders and outlines.

Stitch Steps: Allow the working thread to form a C overlapping your left hand, and tuck the needle under the previously formed "bridge".
Allow the working thread to form a C overlapping yoru left hand, and tuck the needle under /around the lower "leg" of the bridge.
Repeat from step 2.
The sorbello stitch is shaped somewhat like a square.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the upper left hand corner of the square.

Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the upper right hand corner of the square bringing it back to the front at the lower left hand corner of the square.  Pull the thread through but not too tight.
Tuck the needle down under the top line and pull through.
Tuck the needle down under the top line (to the right of the last one) do not pull through
Wrap the working thread behind the needle tip and pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the lower right hand corner of the square.
The eastern stitch is shaped somewhat like an arrow pointed to the upper left hand corner of a square.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the upper left hand corner of the square
Short Description: Knotted stitch forming a textured square or cross pattern.
Notes: Works well for filling or borders.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the upper right hand corner of the square bringing it back to the front at the lower left hand corner of the square.  Pull the thread through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the upper left hand corner of the square bringing it back to the front at the lower right hand corner of the square.  Pull the thread through.
Tuck the needle under the stitch on the left side of the square from the outside in.
Tuck the needle under the stitch on the top of the square from the outside in.  Be sure the working thread is behind the needle and pull through.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the lower right hand corner of the square.
Bring the thread to the front of the fabric at one edge of the shape.
Short Description: A unique stitch with loops and a braided look.
Notes: Adds cultural flair and visual interest.

Stitch Steps: Take the thread to the back of the fabric on the opposite side of the shape.
Short Description: Flat stitches closely packed to fill a shape with smooth coverage.
Notes: Great for lettering and solid shapes.

Stitch Steps: Repeat by making straight stitches side by side until the shape is full.
2 Tips:  Begin in the center of the shape and fill towards the outside edge OR
Draw a few directional lines to keep the stitches evenly spaced
The fishbone stitch is frequently worked on a leaf shape with a 'vein' down the middle.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the tip of the leaf.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric 1/4 inch down the center line, bringing it back out very near the tip of the leaf, but on the left side of the leaf.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric just below the last stitch on the center line, bringing it back out very near the tip of the leaf, but on the right side of the leaf.
Continue making close stitches from the left side to the center, then from the right side to the center until the leaf shape is full.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric.
NOTE:  The gap between stitches on the outside should be twice what the gap is between stitches on the center line for best results.
The raised fishbone stitch is frequently worked on a leaf shape with a 'vein' down the middle.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the tip of the leaf.
Short Description: A filling stitch with overlapping stitches that resemble a fishbone.
Notes: Commonly used for leaves and petals.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle to the back of the fabric 1/4 inch down the center line, bringing it back out very near the tip of the leaf, but on the left side of the leaf.

Take the needle to the back of the fabric just below the last stitch and slightly to the right of the center line, coming back to the front slightly to the left of the center line, making a very small bite.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric just below the last stitch on the right side of the leaf, bringing it back to the front slightly below the last stitch on the left side of the leaf.
Repeat steps 3 & 4 until the leaf is full.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric.
NOTE:  The gap between stitches should be the same on the outside edges as it is on the center line for best results.

Although this stitch can be worked inside many shapes, it looks nicest on a circle.  This stitch is made on a foundation of backstitches around a circle.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric between two backstitches.
Short Description: A 3D version of fishbone with padding underneath.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under the next backstitch in a clockwise direction.  Do not pull through.

Wrap the working thread around the needle crossing in front of the needle and then around behind.  Pull the needle through, pulling the working thread down and to the left to keep stitches close together.
Repeat from step 2 back to the first backstitch, working a second knot in that stitch.
Round 2 and beyond, tuck the needle in the gap between the two stitches on the previous row.  If the stitches are close, you can reveal the gap by pulling the working thread to the right and down.
When the stitches are too close to continue (generally not in the first few rounds) occasionally skip a gap until the entire circle is filled with knots.  Take the needle to the back of the fabric.
The raised cup stitch is created on a foundation of 3 small stitches in a triangle shape.  Bring the thread to the front  in one of the corners.
Short Description: Stitch worked in spiral rows creating a raised circular effect.

Stitch Steps: Tuck the needle under the thread to the right from outside to inside.  Do not pull through.
Wrap the working thread around the needle crossing in front first and then around behind.  Pull the needle through.
Work a second knot on that same stitch.
(Optional) Work a third knot on that same stitch.
Move to the next stitch and work 2 or 3 knots.
Repeat for the last stitch.
For row 2, work a knot between each of the stitches on row 1.

The raised cup stitch can be finished off by taking the needle to the back of the fabric after 2 rows.  Alternatively, it can be gradually condensed by skipping gaps until a little mound is made, or many many rows can be stitched to create a small tube.
Bring the to be Couched thread to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the stitching line.  Lay it in place for the first part of the line.
Short Description: A padded, round stitch forming a cup-like 3D structure.
Notes: Ideal for dramatic texture or sculptural work.

Stitch Steps: At about a stitch length away from the end fo the stitching line, bring the 'Coucher' thread to the front of the fabric, just to one side of the stitching line.
Cross over the to be Couched thread and take the needle to the back of the fabric on the other side of the to be Couched thread tacking it in place.
Repeat for the length of the stitching line, securing the to be Couched thread in place.
At the end of the stitching line, take the to be Couched thread to the back of the fabric and secure.
The cretan stitch is very much like a flattened or opened feather stitch.  It is formed on 4 parallel stitching lines.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the top of the 2nd line.

Take the needle to the back of the fabric a half of a stitch width below where it came out, but on the 4th line, bringing it back to the front even with that stitch on the 3rd line.  Do not pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle tip and then pull through.

Take the needle to the back of the fabric a half of a stitch width below where it came out, but on the 1st line, bringing it back to the front even with that stitch on the 2nd line.  Do not pull through.
Wrap the working thread behind the needle tip and then pull through.
Repeat from step 2.
It is helpful to have both a soft pad or cushion such as a drizzle pad and a needle threader for this stitch. Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the location of the stitch.
Unthread the needle, lay the fabric over the drizzle pad, and stick the needle down into the drizzle pad just far enough for it to stay upright right next to where the thread came out.
Cast on the number of stitches desired:  twist the working thread into a loop with the end of the thread on the bottom.  Place loop on the needle. Repeat for as many cast-ons as desired.
Thread the needle.
Gently pull the needle through, being careful to not let the loop catch any of the cast-on stitches, but instead pull it tightly.
Tie a knot on the backside after each drizzle stitch so they maintain their tightness = better twists.

Needles make a difference to the success of this stitch.  Preferably use a bullion knot needle.  Alternatively use a milliners needle.  Begin by bringing the needle to the front of the fabric at one end of the stitch location.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the other end of the stitch and bring it to the front right next to where it first came out (taking care not to catch any threads) DO NOT PULL THROUGH.
With your dominant hand, wrap the working thread around the needle clockwise a desired number of wraps, but at least enough to fill the length of the stitch plus a few because wraps pull tight.

Holding the wraps (on the needle) with your non-dominant hand (thumb & finger) securely, pull the needle through gently.  Do not let go of those wraps until the wraps are laying down in the location of the stitch.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the end of the stitch

Needles make a difference to the success of this stitch.  Preferably use a bullion knot needle.  Alternatively use a milliners needle.  A Bullion Loop is a bullion knot with extra wraps.  Begin by bringing the needle to the front of the fabric at one end of the stitch location.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the other end of the stitch and bring it to the front right next to where it first came out (taking care not to catch any threads) DO NOT PULL THROUGH.
With your dominant hand, wrap the working thread around the needle clockwise a desired number of wraps, but more than enough to fill the length of the stitch.

Holding the wraps (on the needle) with your non-dominant hand (thumb & finger) securely, pull the needle through gently.  Do not let go of those wraps until the wraps are laying down in the location of the stitch.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the end of the stitch

Needles make a difference to the success of this stitch.  Preferably use a bullion knot needle.  Alternatively use a milliners needle.  A Cast on Bullion has the wraps "cast on" as in knitting.  Begin by bringing the needle to the front of the fabric at one end of the stitch location.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the other end of the stitch and bring it to the front right next to where it first came out (taking care not to catch any threads) DO NOT PULL THROUGH.
Cast on the number of stitches desired:  twist the working thread into a loop with the end of the thread on the bottom.  Place loop on the needle. Repeat for as many cast-ons as desired.

Holding the wraps (on the needle) with your non-dominant hand (thumb & finger) securely, pull the needle through gently.  Do not let go of those wraps until the wraps are laying down in the location of the stitch.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the end of the stitch

This is one of the few stitches worked with a double thread.  Thread the needle and tie both ends together with a knot.  Needles make a difference to the success of this stitch.  Preferably use a bullion knot needle.  Alternatively use a milliners needle.  Begin by bringing the needle to the front of the fabric at one end of the stitch location.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the other end of the stitch and bring it to the front right next to where it first came out (taking care not to catch any threads) DO NOT PULL THROUGH.
Separate the threads and untwist the needle so there is a loop on the left and a loop on the right of the needle.
Cast on wraps alternating between the left and right sides until the desired number of stitches have been cast on.
Bring the threads back together and make sure they are the same length.

Holding the wraps (on the needle) with your non-dominant hand (thumb & finger) securely, pull the needle through gently.  Do not let go of those wraps until the wraps are laying down in the location of the stitch.
Take the needle to the back of the fabric at the end of the stitch

This stitch requires at least a thin strip of cardstock, or ideally a graduated width tool such as a slipper, hereafter refered to as the tool.  Mark the vein of the leaf before you begin.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric at the tip end of the vein line.

Take the needle to the back of the fabric just barely below the tip on the vein line.  Do not pull through completely until you have put the tool in the loop, then pull it snug to hold the loop in place.
Lay the tool flat on the fabric so you can see the vein line on the left of the tool.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric just below the last stitch on the vein line.

Flip the tool over so you can see the vein line on the right of the tool.  Take the needle to the back of the fabric just below the last stitch on the vein line and pull through.  The new loop will form around the tool.  Keep them neat and next to one another without crossing.
Repeat from step 4 until the desired number of loops or under the vein line is full.
Lay the tool flat on the fabric so you can see the vein line on the left of the tool.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric just below the last stitch on the vein line.
Tuck the needle under all of the loops (easiest on one side of the tool).  Remove the tool.  Pull the working thread and take the needle to the back at the base of the leaf forming the stem.
This stitch is created on a foundation of 2 rows of backstitches, with the stitches matching row to row.  Bring the needle to the front of the fabric just above the first stitch in the bottom row.
Tuck the needle under the second stitch in the top row going outward.
Tuck the needle under the first stitch in the top row going inward.
Tuck the needle under the third stitch in the bottom row going outward.
Tuck the needle under the previous stitch in the bottom row going inward.
Continue in this fashion always going outward under a new (empty) stitch and coming back under a used (already has 1 thread) stitch alternating top and bottom.
Begin by bringing the needle to the front of the fabric at the beginning of the stitch line.
Form a chain stitch with the tip to the left of the stitch line.
Form a second chaing stitch with the tip to the right of the stitch line.
Repeat from Step 2.
Bring the needle from the back of the fabric to the left of the start of the sitching line.
Take the needle down on the stitching line a stitch length from the start of the stitching line and come up to the right of the stitching line matching the initial stitch.
Take the needle down on the stitching line at the same place as the last stitch, forming a V.   Come out a stitch length down the stitching line.
Weave the needle under both arms of the v and take it down near where it came out.
Begin by bringing the needle to the front of the fabric at the top of the triangle.
Short Description: Compact knot used for filling areas.

Stitch Steps: Take the needle down at the bottom right corner of the intended triangle, bringing it back to the front of the fabric at the bottom left corner.
Slide the needle under the straight stitch from the top down coming out above the bottom line of the triangle.
Slide the needle under the straight stitch from the top down, this time coming out towards the bottom line of the triangle, DO NOT PULL THROUGH
Make certain the working thread is under the needle, then pull through.
Take the needle down near the bottom left corner of the triangle, tacking the loop in place.
